message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Optimization-Based Collision Avoidance
Paper Abstract: This article presents a novel method for exactly reformulating nondifferentiable collision avoidance constraints into smooth, differentiable constraints using strong duality of convex optimization. We focus on a controlled object whose goal is to avoid obstacles while moving in an n-dimensional space. The proposed reformulation is exact, does not introduce any approximations, and applies to general obstacles and controlled objects that can be represented as the union of convex sets. We connect our results with the notion of signed distance, which is widely used in traditional trajectory generation algorithms. Our method can be applied to generic navigation and trajectory planning tasks, and the smoothness property allows the use of general-purpose gradient- and Hessian-based optimization algorithms. Finally, in case a collision cannot be avoided, our framework allows us to find "least-intrusive" trajectories, measured in terms of penetration. We demonstrate the efficacy of our framework on an automated parking problem, where our numerical experiments suggest that the proposed method is robust and enables real-time optimization-based trajectory planning in tight environments. Sample code of our example is provided at https://github.com/XiaojingGeorgeZhang/OBCA.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've completed a web search on trajectory planning. Here's what I found:

## Overview

Trajectory optimization is the process of designing a trajectory that minimizes (or maximizes) some measure of performance while satisfying a set of constraints.(no content)Generally speaking, trajectory optimization is a technique for computing an open-loop solution to an optimal control problem.

## Applications

There are a wide variety of applications for trajectory optimization, primarily in robotics: industry, manipulation, walking, path-planning, and aerospace. Some specific examples include:

- Robotic manipulators require trajectory optimization, where a 7-DOF robotic arm's redundancy can be used to optimize a trajectory to avoid obstacles or minimize joint torque.
- Trajectory optimization is often used to compute trajectories for quadrotor helicopters.
- Applications include path planning for autonomous vehicles, aerial robotics for unmanned aerial vehicles, manipulation for robotic arms, and footstep planning for legged robots.

## Related Concepts

In robotics and motion planning, kinodynamic planning is a class of problems for which velocity, acceleration, and force/torque bounds must be satisfied, together with kinematic constraints such as avoiding obstacles.

The search results also covered various planning algorithms and approaches used to solve trajectory planning problems in different contexts.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of convex sets:

## Definition

In geometry, a set of points is convex if it contains every line segment between two points in the set. More formally, a subset C of a vector space or affine space is convex if, for all x and y in C, the line segment connecting x and y is included in C.

## Examples

A solid cube is a convex set, but anything that is hollow or has an indent, such as a crescent shape, is not convex.(no content)The convex subsets of the real numbers are the intervals and the points of the real numbers. Some examples of convex subsets of the Euclidean plane are solid regular polygons, solid triangles, and intersections of solid triangles.

## Key Properties

- Convexity is invariant under affine transformations.
- A convex set in a real or complex topological vector space is path-connected (and therefore also connected).
- The intersection of convex sets is convex.

## Applications

Convex geometry is the branch of geometry studying convex sets, mainly in Euclidean space. Convex sets occur naturally in many areas: computational geometry, convex analysis, discrete geometry, functional analysis, geometry of numbers, integral geometry, linear programming, probability theory, game theory, etc.

Web search results for query: "Convex optimization"

Links: [{"title":"Convex optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convex_optimization"},{"title":"Category:Convex optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Convex_optimization"},{"title":"Talk:Convex optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Convex_optimization"},{"title":"Conic optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conic_optimization"},{"title":"Convex function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convex_function"},{"title":"Convex analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convex_analysis"},{"title":"Template:Boyd Vandenberghe Convex Optimization 2004 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Boyd_Vandenberghe_Convex_Optimization_2004"},{"title":"Perturbation function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perturbation_function"},{"title":"Biconvex optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biconvex_optimization"},{"title":"Duality (optimization) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duality_(optimization)"}]

## Convex Optimization - Search Results

Convex optimization is a subfield of mathematical optimization that studies the problem of minimizing convex functions over convex sets (or, equivalently, maximizing concave functions over convex sets).

### Key Properties

Every point that is local minimum is also a global minimum in convex optimization problems, which is a fundamental advantage that makes these problems particularly tractable.

### Solution Methods

The search results identify several approaches to solving convex optimization problems:

- **Unconstrained Problems**: Gradient descent is an efficient algorithm for unconstrained minimization, and Newton's method can be used for unconstrained problems with a general convex objective that is twice-differentiable, reducing a general unconstrained convex problem to a sequence of quadratic problems.

- **Constrained Problems**: For problems with inequality constraints, a common approach is to reduce them to unconstrained problems by adding a barrier function to the objective function.

- **Other Methods**: Subgradient methods can be implemented simply and are widely used.

### Applications

Convex optimization can be applied to portfolio optimization, worst-case risk analysis, optimal advertising, variations of statistical regression, model fitting (particularly multiclass classification), and electricity generation optimization.

### Software Tools

The software ecosystem for convex optimization has two main categories: solvers and modeling tools, where solvers implement algorithms and modeling tools allow users to specify optimizations in higher-level syntax while managing transformations.

Web search results for query: "Gradient descent"

Links: [{"title":"Gradient descent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gradient_descent"},{"title":"Stochastic gradient descent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_gradient_descent"},{"title":"Conjugate gradient method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conjugate_gradient_method"},{"title":"Descent direction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Descent_direction"},{"title":"Vanishing gradient problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vanishing_gradient_problem"},{"title":"Gradient - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gradient"},{"title":"Local search (optimization) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_search_(optimization)"},{"title":"Limited-memory BFGS - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Limited-memory_BFGS"},{"title":"Batch normalization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Batch_normalisation"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of gradient descent:

## Overview

Gradient descent is a method for unconstrained mathematical optimization.(no content)It is a first-order iterative algorithm for minimizing a differentiable multivariate function.

## How It Works

The idea is to take repeated steps in the opposite direction of the gradient (or approximate gradient) of the function to find a minimum. In practical terms, the amount of time they travel before taking another measurement is the step size.

## Key Properties

Gradient descent works in spaces of any number of dimensions, even in infinite-dimensional ones. However, the gradient descent can take many iterations to compute a local minimum with a required accuracy, if the curvature in different directions is very different for the given function.

## Variants and Related Methods

A simple extension of gradient descent, stochastic gradient descent, serves as the most basic algorithm used for training most deep networks today. Additionally, the gradient descent can be modified via momentums (Nesterov, Polyak, and Frank–Wolfe) and heavy-ball parameters (exponential moving averages and positive-negative momentum). The main examples of such optimizers are Adam, DiffGrad, Yogi, AdaBelief, etc.

Links: [{"title":"Gradient descent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gradient_descent"},{"title":"Stochastic gradient descent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_gradient_descent"},{"title":"Conjugate gradient method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conjugate_gradient_method"},{"title":"Descent direction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Descent_direction"},{"title":"Vanishing gradient problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vanishing_gradient_problem"},{"title":"Gradient - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gradient"},{"title":"Local search (optimization) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_search_(optimization)"},{"title":"Limited-memory BFGS - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Limited-memory_BFGS"},{"title":"Batch normalization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Batch_normalisation"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of gradient descent:

## Overview

Gradient descent is a method for unconstrained mathematical optimization.(no content)It is a first-order iterative algorithm for minimizing a differentiable multivariate function.

## How It Works

The idea is to take repeated steps in the opposite direction of the gradient (or approximate gradient) of the function to find a minimum. In practical terms, the amount of time they travel before taking another measurement is the step size.

## Key Properties

Gradient descent works in spaces of any number of dimensions, even in infinite-dimensional ones. However, the gradient descent can take many iterations to compute a local minimum with a required accuracy, if the curvature in different directions is very different for the given function.

## Variants and Related Methods

A simple extension of gradient descent, stochastic gradient descent, serves as the most basic algorithm used for training most deep networks today. Additionally, the gradient descent can be modified via momentums (Nesterov, Polyak, and Frank–Wolfe) and heavy-ball parameters (exponential moving averages and positive-negative momentum). The main examples of such optimizers are Adam, DiffGrad, Yogi, AdaBelief, etc.

## Collision Avoidance - Search Results

The search returned comprehensive information about collision avoidance systems across multiple domains. Here's a summary of the key findings:

### General Definition
Collision avoidance in transportation is the maintenance of systems and practices designed to prevent vehicles (such as aircraft, motor vehicles, ships, cranes and trains) from colliding with each other.

### Aviation
A Traffic Alert and Collision Avoidance System (TCAS), also known as an Airborne Collision Avoidance System (ACAS), is an aircraft collision avoidance system designed to reduce the incidence of mid-air collisions between aircraft. It monitors the airspace around an aircraft for other aircraft equipped with a corresponding active transponder, independent of air traffic control, and warns pilots of the presence of other transponder-equipped aircraft which may present a threat of collision.

### Automotive
A collision avoidance system (CAS), also known as a pre-crash system, forward collision warning system (FCW), or collision mitigation system, is an advanced driver-assistance system designed to prevent or reduce the severity of a collision.(no content)Once an impending collision is detected, these systems provide a warning to the driver. When the collision becomes imminent, they can take action autonomously without any driver input (by braking or steering or both).

### Maritime
Maritime Collision Avoidance Systems (MCAS) are integrated technologies used to prevent collisions and groundings at sea by enhancing vessel situational awareness.

### Spacecraft
Spacecraft collision avoidance is the implementation and study of processes minimizing the chance of orbiting spacecraft inadvertently colliding with other orbiting objects.

### Networking
In computer networking and telecommunication, collision-avoidance methods try to avoid resource contention by attempting to avoid simultaneous attempts to access the same resource.

Web search results for query: "Signed distance function"

Links: [{"title":"Signed distance function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signed_distance_function"},{"title":"Talk:Signed distance function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Signed_distance_function"},{"title":"Distance transform - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distance_transform"},{"title":"Ray marching - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ray_marching"},{"title":"Distance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distance"},{"title":"Total variation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Total_variation"},{"title":"Support function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Support_function"},{"title":"Signed measure - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real_measure"},{"title":"Gilbert–Johnson–Keerthi distance algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gilbert-Johnson-Keerthi_distance_algorithm"},{"title":"Metric space - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metric_(mathematics)"}]

## Signed Distance Function

A signed distance function (SDF), or signed distance field, is the orthogonal distance of a given point to the boundary of a set in a metric space (such as the surface of a geometric shape), with the sign determined by whether or not the point is in the interior or exterior of the set.

### Mathematical Properties

If the boundary of the set has a piecewise smooth boundary, the signed distance function is differentiable almost everywhere, and its gradient satisfies the eikonal equation.(no content)The signed distance function is a differentiable extension of the normal vector field.

### Computational Methods

Algorithms for calculating the signed distance function include the efficient fast marching method, fast sweeping method and the more general level-set method.

### Applications

Signed distance functions are applied, for example, in real-time rendering, such as the method of SDF ray marching, and computer vision. Additionally, SDFs can be defined for many fractals, and sphere tracing is often used for 3D fractal rendering.(no content)Uniformly-sampled signed distance fields have been used for GPU-accelerated font smoothing, and signed distance fields can also be used for 3D solid modelling.

Web search results for query: "Strong duality optimization"

Links: [{"title":"Strong duality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strong_duality"},{"title":"Duality (optimization) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duality_(optimization)"},{"title":"Dual linear program - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dual_linear_program"},{"title":"Slater's condition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slater's_condition"},{"title":"Semidefinite programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semidefinite_programming"},{"title":"Talk:Duality (optimization) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Duality_(optimization)"},{"title":"Fenchel's duality theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fenchel's_duality_theorem"},{"title":"Duality gap - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duality_gap"},{"title":"Linear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming"},{"title":"Weak duality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weak_duality"}]

## Strong Duality in Optimization

Here's what I found about strong duality optimization:

### Definition

Strong duality is a condition in mathematical optimization in which the primal optimal objective and the dual optimal objective are equal.(no content)By definition, strong duality holds if and only if the duality gap is equal to 0.

### Key Concepts

Strong duality states that the primal optimal objective and the dual optimal objective are equal, and it only holds in certain cases. This contrasts with weak duality, which allows for a gap between the primal and dual solutions.

### Conditions for Strong Duality

If the primal problem is convex and bounded from below, and there exists a point in which all nonlinear constraints are strictly satisfied (Slater's condition), then the optimal solution to the dual program equals the optimal solution of the primal program.(no content)Slater's condition is a sufficient condition for strong duality to hold for a convex optimization problem, and it informally states that the feasible region must have an interior point.

### Linear Programming

The strong duality theorem states that if the primal has an optimal solution, x*, then the dual also has an optimal solution, y*, and c^T x* = b^T y*.

### Semidefinite Programming

Unlike linear programs where every dual linear program has optimal objective equal to the primal objective, not every semidefinite program (SDP) satisfies strong duality; a sufficient condition for strong duality to hold for an SDP problem is Slater's condition.

Links: [{"title":"Strong duality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strong_duality"},{"title":"Duality (optimization) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duality_(optimization)"},{"title":"Dual linear program - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dual_linear_program"},{"title":"Slater's condition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slater's_condition"},{"title":"Semidefinite programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semidefinite_programming"},{"title":"Talk:Duality (optimization) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Duality_(optimization)"},{"title":"Fenchel's duality theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fenchel's_duality_theorem"},{"title":"Duality gap - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duality_gap"},{"title":"Linear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming"},{"title":"Weak duality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weak_duality"}]

## Strong Duality in Optimization

Here's what I found about strong duality optimization:

### Definition

Strong duality is a condition in mathematical optimization in which the primal optimal objective and the dual optimal objective are equal.(no content)By definition, strong duality holds if and only if the duality gap is equal to 0.

### Key Concepts

Strong duality states that the primal optimal objective and the dual optimal objective are equal, and it only holds in certain cases. This contrasts with weak duality, which allows for a gap between the primal and dual solutions.

### Conditions for Strong Duality

If the primal problem is convex and bounded from below, and there exists a point in which all nonlinear constraints are strictly satisfied (Slater's condition), then the optimal solution to the dual program equals the optimal solution of the primal program.(no content)Slater's condition is a sufficient condition for strong duality to hold for a convex optimization problem, and it informally states that the feasible region must have an interior point.

### Linear Programming

The strong duality theorem states that if the primal has an optimal solution, x*, then the dual also has an optimal solution, y*, and c^T x* = b^T y*.

### Semidefinite Programming

Unlike linear programs where every dual linear program has optimal objective equal to the primal objective, not every semidefinite program (SDP) satisfies strong duality; a sufficient condition for strong duality to hold for an SDP problem is Slater's condition.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "mathematical optimization reformulation constraints"

Links: [{"title":"Mathematical optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_optimization"},{"title":"Constrained optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constrained_optimization"},{"title":"Lagrange multiplier - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lagrange_multiplier"},{"title":"Bilevel optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bilevel_optimization"},{"title":"Quadratic programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quadratic_programming"},{"title":"Integer programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integer_programming"},{"title":"Linear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming"},{"title":"Multi-objective optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-objective_optimization"},{"title":"Nonlinear programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_programming"},{"title":"Convex optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convex_optimization"}]

Here are the search results for "mathematical optimization reformulation constraints":

## Key Findings

**Reformulation Techniques for Constrained Optimization**

If a constrained problem has only equality constraints, the method of Lagrange multipliers can be used to convert it into an unconstrained problem whose number of variables is the original number of variables plus the original number of equality constraints.(no content)For simple problems, the idea is to substitute the constraint into the objective function to create a composite function that incorporates the effect of the constraint.

**Specific Problem Classes and Transformations**

Geometric programming is a technique whereby objective and inequality constraints expressed as posynomials and equality constraints as monomials can be transformed into a convex program.(no content)The special class of concave fractional programs can be transformed to a convex optimization problem.

**Bilevel Optimization Reformulation**

Certain bilevel programs, notably those having a convex lower level and satisfying a regularity condition, can be reformulated to single level by replacing the lower-level problem by its Karush-Kuhn-Tucker conditions. This yields a single-level mathematical program with complementarity constraints, i.e., MPECs.

**Converting Equality Constraints in Convex Optimization**

The set of all solutions to equality constraints can be presented in a parametric form, and substituting this into the original problem reduces the number of variables by the rank of the constraint matrix.

These reformulation techniques are widely used to convert difficult optimization problems into forms that are easier to solve algorithmically.

Excellent! I've successfully completed the analysis of the "Optimization-Based Collision Avoidance" paper. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Contribution (proposes a novel method)

**Triples Identified:** 8 entities with proper Wikipedia URLs

**Entity Breakdown:**
- **2 Tasks:** Collision avoidance, Trajectory optimization
- **4 Methods:** Convex optimization, Constrained optimization (proposed), Signed distance function, Gradient descent
- **2 Concepts:** Strong duality, Convex set

**Key Triple (Proposed):**
The paper proposes a novel approach to **Constrained optimization** by reformulating nondifferentiable collision avoidance constraints into smooth, differentiable constraints using strong duality from convex optimization.

**Validation:** ✅ PASSED
- All Wikipedia URLs verified
- Paper type correctly classified as "contribution"
- At least 1 "proposes" relation present (required for contribution papers)
- All validation requirements met
